# Stablecoin Issuance and Services Licensing Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Issuance and Services Authorization and Licensing Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for obtaining and maintaining authorization to issue stablecoins and/or provide related services in the Republic of Bulgaria, in full compliance with Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 on Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA). The policy ensures alignment with the supervisory expectations of the Bulgarian Financial Supervision Commission (FSC) and manages associated regulatory risks.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to all business units, subsidiaries, and personnel involved in or planning to engage in:
*   The issuance of asset-referenced tokens (ARTs) or e-money tokens (EMTs) as defined under MiCA.
*   The provision of crypto-asset services related to stablecoins, including custody, trading, and exchange.
*   Strategic planning, legal, compliance, risk management, and operational functions supporting stablecoin activities.

## 3. Definitions
| Term | Definition |
| :--- | :--- |
| **MiCA** | Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 on Markets in Crypto-Assets. |
| **FSC** | The Bulgarian Financial Supervision Commission (ФКН), the designated national competent authority for MiCA implementation in Bulgaria. |
| **ART (Asset-Referenced Token)** | A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing multiple fiat currencies, commodities, crypto-assets, or a combination thereof. |
| **EMT (E-money Token)** | A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing a single fiat currency. |
| **CASP (Crypto-Asset Service Provider)** | A legal person providing one or more crypto-asset services. |
| **Authorization** | The formal grant of permission by the FSC to issue stablecoins or provide crypto-asset services. |
| **White Paper** | The mandatory disclosure document for crypto-assets requiring prior authorization under MiCA. |

## 4. Policy Statement
It is the policy of [Company Name] to seek and maintain all required regulatory authorizations before issuing any stablecoin (ART or EMT) or offering related crypto-asset services in or from Bulgaria. All activities must be conducted in strict adherence to the MiCA framework, subordinate Bulgarian national legislation, and the direct supervisory requirements of the FSC. Compliance with this policy is mandatory, and any unlicensed activity is prohibited.

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1 Pre-Application Phase
1.  **Project Assessment:** The initiating business unit must submit a formal Project Proposal to the Legal and Compliance Department, detailing the type of stablecoin (ART/EMT) or service, target market, and operational model.
2.  **Gap Analysis:** Legal and Compliance will conduct a comprehensive MiCA gap analysis against the proposal, outlining capital, governance, custody, white paper, and operational requirements.
3.  **Engagement with FSC:** Prior to formal application, Legal and Compliance will, in coordination with senior management, initiate a preliminary dialogue with the FSC to present the project outline and seek informal guidance.
4.  **Internal Approval:** A formal business case, including the gap analysis and estimated compliance costs, must be approved by the Executive Committee.

### 5.2 Application Preparation & Submission
1.  **Application Team:** A dedicated cross-functional project team (Legal, Compliance, Risk, Finance, IT, Operations) will be formed to prepare the authorization application.
2.  **Documentation Drafting:** The team will prepare all required documentation, including:
    *   A MiCA-compliant White Paper.
    *   Detailed business plan and financial projections.
    *   Governance, risk management, and internal control frameworks.
    *   IT security and operational resilience policies.
    *   Complaint-handling and conflict-of-interest procedures.
    *   Proof of required capital (€350,000 for CASPs, €X for issuers as per MiCA).
3.  **Internal Review:** All documentation is subject to a rigorous internal review process, culminating in sign-off by the Head of Compliance and General Counsel.
4.  **Formal Submission:** The complete application package will be submitted to the FSC via its official channels, initiating the statutory review period (up to 120 days for issuers, 25 working days for CASPs, extendable by FSC).

### 5.3 Post-Authorization & Ongoing Compliance
1.  **License Maintenance:** The Compliance Department is responsible for maintaining the authorization, managing ongoing reporting obligations (regular and ad-hoc) to the FSC, and ensuring timely renewal.
2.  **Material Change Management:** Any material change to the business model, governance, or White Paper requires prior notification to, and in some cases approval from, the FSC, following an internal review process.
3.  **Record Keeping:** All records, including transaction data, client complaints, and compliance reports, must be maintained for at least five years, in accordance with MiCA Article 78.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
All personnel must adhere to the following core requirements derived from MiCA:
*   **Prudential Requirements:** Maintain the required level of own funds at all times.
*   **Custody & Safekeeping:** Ensure full segregation of client assets and use of secure, distributed ledger technology or other secure means.
*   **Governance:** Implement fit-and-proper assessments for all management body members and robust governance arrangements.
*   **Transparency & Disclosure:** Publish and maintain an approved White Paper, provide periodic disclosures, and make all mandatory pre-contractual information available to clients.
*   **Market Conduct:** Operate with honesty, fairness, and professionalism; prevent market abuse (MANSA applies to crypto-assets under MiCA).
*   **FSC Reporting:** Submit all required regulatory reports accurately and by the FSC's deadlines.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually** by the Legal and Compliance Department.
*   **Immediately** following any material change to MiCA, its implementing technical standards, or relevant Bulgarian national law.
*   **Immediately** following any material change in the company's authorized activities or upon request from the FSC.
All revisions require approval from the Chief Compliance Officer and General Counsel.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to implement the following primary regulatory requirements:
*   **Regulation (EU) 2023/1114** of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2023 on Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA), particularly Titles III (ARTs), IV (EMTs), and V (CASP Authorization).
*   **Bulgarian National Implementing Legislation** (to be specified once adopted, e.g., "Law on Markets in Crypto-Assets").
*   **Directives, Guidelines, and Q&As** issued by the Bulgarian Financial Supervision Commission (FSC) pertaining to MiCA implementation.
*   **Related Financial Services Regulations:** Including but not limited to anti-money laundering directives (AMLD), the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID II) principles applied by analogy, and the Market Abuse Regulation (MAR/ MANSA).

---
**Policy Owner:** Chief Compliance Officer  
**Approved By:** [Name of CEO/Board Member]  
**Effective Date:** [Date]  
**Version:** 1.0
```

# Stablecoin Capital Adequacy and Reserve Management Policy

## 1. Policy Title
**Capital Adequacy, Reserve Management, and Liquidity Protocol Policy for Asset-Referenced Token (ART) and E-Money Token (EMT) Issuance**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to ensure [Company Name] maintains adequate capital, holds sufficient reserves, and implements robust liquidity protocols for all issued stablecoins (categorized as Asset-Referenced Tokens (ARTs) or E-Money Tokens (EMTs) under MiCA). The primary objectives are to:
*   Ensure full 1:1 backing of all tokens in circulation with high-quality liquid assets.
*   Maintain capital buffers to absorb potential losses and ensure operational resilience.
*   Guarantee daily redemption rights for token holders.
*   Ensure full compliance with Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (Markets in Crypto-Assets - MiCA), specifically Articles 31-35.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to all departments, personnel, and third-party service providers involved in the issuance, management, reserve custody, redemption, and liquidity provisioning of [Company Name]'s stablecoins. It covers all stages of the token lifecycle.

## 3. Definitions
*   **ART (Asset-Referenced Token):** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing another value or right, or a combination thereof, including one or more official currencies.
*   **EMT (E-Money Token):** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing the value of one official currency.
*   **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA):** Assets as defined in MiCA Article 32(3) and further specified in this policy, which are highly liquid, low-risk, and can be easily and immediately converted to cash to meet redemption requests.
*   **Reserve of Assets:** The total pool of assets backing the stablecoins in circulation, maintained on a 1:1 basis.
*   **Capital Buffer:** Own funds held by the issuer in addition to the reserve of assets, intended to cover operational risks and potential losses.
*   **Liquidity Protocol:** The operational procedures and systems that ensure the timely processing of redemptions and management of the reserve portfolio.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to operating with the highest standards of transparency, security, and regulatory compliance. We hereby mandate:
1.  **1:1 Backing Requirement:** At all times, the value of the Reserve of Assets must equal or exceed the aggregate value of all stablecoins issued and in circulation.
2.  **HQLA Reserve Composition:** The Reserve of Assets shall be composed exclusively of High-Quality Liquid Assets as defined in Section 5.1. The reserve shall be segregated, ring-fenced, and held with regulated custodians.
3.  **Capital Adequacy:** [Company Name] shall maintain a permanent capital buffer (own funds) in accordance with the higher of: (a) the requirements of MiCA Article 35, or (b) 2% of the average amount of the reserve assets.
4.  **Daily Redemption:** All token holders have the right to redeem their tokens at par value, in the referenced currency, on any business day.
5.  **Prohibition of Interest:** No interest shall be paid to stablecoin holders.
6.  **Transparency:** Regular, detailed reports on the composition, valuation, and audit results of the Reserve of Assets will be published.

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1 Reserve Asset Management
*   **Eligible Assets:** The Reserve of Assets may only include:
    *   Deposits with credit institutions.
    *   Government bonds (sovereign debt) from EEA Member States, with a credit assessment of at least 1 from a recognized agency.
    *   High-quality corporate bonds.
    *   Short-term money market instruments.
    *   **Explicitly Excluded:** No crypto-assets, own funds, or illiquid assets shall be included in the reserve.
*   **Custody:** All reserve assets must be held with one or more EU-authorized credit institutions or investment firms. A minimum of two-thirds of the reserve must be held in deposits.
*   **Diversification:** No single asset or issuer (excluding sovereign debt of EEA states) shall constitute more than 5% of the total reserve.
*   **Valuation:** The reserve portfolio shall be valued daily at mark-to-market or mark-to-model prices by the Finance Department.

### 5.2 Capital Buffer Calculation & Maintenance
*   The Capital Buffer shall be calculated monthly based on the average amount of reserve assets over the preceding six months.
*   The buffer must be held in liquid assets, separate from the operational accounts of the company.
*   The buffer can only be used to cover operational losses and must be replenished within 30 days if utilized.

### 5.3 Liquidity and Redemption Protocol
1.  **Redemption Request Submission:** Token holders may submit redemption requests 24/7 through the official platform.
2.  **Processing Timeline:** Requests received on a business day before 12:00 PM CET will be processed for same-day settlement (T+1). Later requests will be processed the next business day.
3.  **Settlement:** Redemptions are settled via bank transfer to a verified account in the referenced fiat currency.
4.  **Liquidity Stress Testing:** The Treasury Department will conduct weekly stress tests simulating extreme redemption scenarios (e.g., 20% of tokens redeemed in 24 hours) to ensure the HQLA portfolio can be liquidated without significant loss.

### 5.4 Audit and Reporting
*   **Internal Reporting:** Daily reserve composition and valuation reports to the Chief Compliance Officer (CCO) and Chief Financial Officer (CFO).
*   **External Audit:** A quarterly statutory audit of the Reserve of Assets by an independent, EU-authorized auditor.
*   **Public Disclosure:** Publication of a monthly Reserve Report on the company website, detailing the breakdown of assets, their valuations, and the auditor's attestation.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   The **Chief Compliance Officer (CCO)** is the policy owner and is responsible for overall oversight.
*   The **Treasury Department** is responsible for the day-to-day management, investment, and rebalancing of the Reserve of Assets.
*   The **Finance Department** is responsible for daily valuation, capital buffer calculation, and financial reporting.
*   The **Technology Department** is responsible for implementing and maintaining the technical systems for the redemption protocol.
*   All employees must complete annual training on this policy.
*   Any breach or suspected breach of this policy must be reported immediately to the CCO.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually** as part of the standard compliance review cycle.
*   **Ad-hoc** following any material change in MiCA regulatory technical standards (RTS) or implementing acts.
*   **Ad-hoc** following any internal incident affecting reserves or liquidity.
The next scheduled review date is: **[Date, One Year from Effective Date]**

This policy is designed to ensure compliance with the following primary regulatory provisions:
*   **Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 on Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA):**
    *   **Article 31:** Obligation to have a reserve of assets.
    *   **Article 32:** Composition and management of the reserve of assets.
    *   **Article 33:** Custody of reserve assets.
    *   **Article 34:** Rights of token holders (redemption).
    *   **Article 35:** Own funds (capital) requirements.
*   **Related Delegated Acts & RTS:** This policy will be updated to align with all relevant Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) and Implementing Technical Standards (ITS) adopted by the European Banking Authority (EBA) and European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) pertaining to Articles 31-35.

# CRYPTO-ASSET SERVICE PROVIDER DISCLOSURE AND CONSUMER PROTECTION POLICY

## 1. POLICY TITLE
**Comprehensive Disclosure and Consumer Protection Policy for Crypto-Asset Services**

## 2. PURPOSE AND SCOPE

### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes comprehensive procedures to ensure compliance with Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) Articles 36-40, specifically addressing consumer protection, disclosure obligations, whitepaper requirements, redemption procedures, and risk communication protocols. The policy aims to ensure transparency, fairness, and informed decision-making for all consumers of our crypto-asset services.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
- All crypto-asset services offered by the organization
- All employees, contractors, and third-party service providers involved in crypto-asset service delivery
- All marketing, sales, and client communication activities
- All crypto-asset offerings, including asset-referenced tokens, e-money tokens, and other crypto-assets
- All jurisdictions where MiCA regulations apply to our operations

## 3. DEFINITIONS

**Crypto-Asset:** A digital representation of value or rights that can be transferred and stored electronically using distributed ledger technology or similar technology.

**Whitepaper:** A detailed document containing mandatory disclosures as specified under MiCA Article 36.

**Redemption Procedure:** The process by which holders of asset-referenced tokens or e-money tokens can exchange them for the referenced assets or funds.

**Qualified Investor:** An investor meeting specific criteria as defined under MiCA who may receive modified disclosure requirements.

**Retail Holder:** Any natural person who is acting for purposes other than their trade, business, or profession.

## 4. POLICY STATEMENT

Our organization is committed to the highest standards of consumer protection and transparency. We will:
- Provide clear, fair, and not misleading information to all consumers
- Ensure all crypto-asset offerings are accompanied by a compliant whitepaper
- Establish transparent redemption procedures for relevant tokens
- Communicate risks in a manner that is understandable to the target audience
- Maintain all disclosures in accordance with MiCA requirements
- Update information promptly when material changes occur

## 5. PROCEDURES

### 5.1 Whitepaper Development and Approval Process

#### 5.1.1 Content Requirements
All whitepapers must contain, at minimum:
- Details about the issuer and project team
- Description of the crypto-asset and its intended purpose
- Underlying technology and protocols
- Associated risks (technical, market, regulatory)
- Rights and obligations attached to the crypto-asset
- Detailed redemption procedures (where applicable)
- Environmental impact assessment
- Complaint handling procedures

#### 5.1.2 Approval Workflow
1. **Draft Creation:** Product team creates initial whitepaper draft
2. **Legal Review:** Legal department verifies regulatory compliance
3. **Risk Assessment:** Risk management team validates risk disclosures
4. **Final Approval:** Chief Compliance Officer approves final version
5. **Filing:** Whitepaper filed with relevant national competent authority (where required)
6. **Publication:** Published on company website with clear access

### 5.2 Redemption Procedures

#### 5.2.1 For Asset-Referenced Tokens
- Establish clear, publicly available redemption policies
- Maintain adequate reserves to support redemption requests
- Process redemption requests within [X] business days
- Provide multiple redemption channels (direct, through authorized partners)
- Document all redemption transactions with audit trails

#### 5.2.2 For E-Money Tokens
- Ensure redemption at par value
- Maintain 1:1 backing with relevant fiat currency
- Process redemptions without undue delay
- Provide clear instructions for redemption process

### 5.3 Risk Communication Protocols

#### 5.3.1 Standard Risk Warnings
All communications must include:
- "Crypto-assets are highly volatile and may result in loss of capital"
- "Regulatory frameworks are evolving and may impact asset value"
- "Technological risks including cybersecurity threats exist"
- "Past performance is not indicative of future results"

#### 5.3.2 Communication Channels
- **Website:** Dedicated risk disclosure section
- **Marketing Materials:** Prominent risk warnings in all materials
- **Platform Interface:** Real-time risk notifications during transactions
- **Customer Communications:** Regular risk updates via email/newsletter

### 5.4 Disclosure Updates and Material Changes

#### 5.4.1 Update Triggers
- Material changes to the crypto-asset or its underlying technology
- Significant changes to the issuer's financial position
- Regulatory changes affecting the offering
- Changes to redemption procedures or rights

#### 5.4.2 Update Process
1. Identify material change requiring disclosure update
2. Prepare amended whitepaper or supplemental disclosure
3. Obtain necessary approvals (per section 5.1.2)
4. File with competent authority (where required)
5. Notify existing holders via registered email
6. Update website and all public materials
7. Maintain version control and archive previous versions

## 6. COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS

### 6.1 Mandatory Disclosures
- Whitepaper available in language(s) of target market
- Clear identification of issuer and contact information
- Date of whitepaper publication and last update
- Disclaimer stating whitepaper is not a prospectus
- Warning that crypto-assets are not covered by investor compensation schemes

- Document all material change decisions and approvals
- Retain records of all redemption transactions
- Archive all marketing and communication materials

- Quarterly updates on regulatory changes affecting disclosures
- Specialized training for compliance and legal teams

### 6.4 Monitoring and Reporting

- Quarterly audit of redemption procedures
- Annual comprehensive policy review
- Immediate reporting of material breaches to Compliance Officer

- **Quarterly:** Policy effectiveness assessment
- **Annually:** Comprehensive policy review and update

### 7.2 Trigger Events for Immediate Review

- Material non-compliance incidents
- Significant changes to business model or offerings
- Regulatory findings or sanctions

### 7.3 Review Process
1. Compliance team initiates review
2. Stakeholder consultation (legal, risk, operations)
3. Draft revisions and impact assessment
4. Approval by Policy Review Committee
5. Implementation and communication
6. Training on updated policy

## 8. REFERENCES TO REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS

### 8.1 Primary Regulations
- **MiCA Article 36:** Whitepaper requirements for crypto-assets
- **MiCA Article 37:** Whitepaper requirements for asset-referenced tokens
- **MiCA Article 38:** Whitepaper requirements for e-money tokens
- **MiCA Article 39:** Disclosure requirements for crypto-asset services

- MiCA Article 42: Liability for misleading or untrue information

# Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (AML/CTF) Policy

## 1. Policy Title
**Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (AML/CTF) Policy**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive, risk-based framework to prevent, detect, and report money laundering (ML) and terrorist financing (TF) activities. It is designed to ensure full compliance with the Bulgarian Measures Against Money Laundering Act (MAMLA), relevant EU Directives (including AMLD 5 and 6), and the supervisory requirements of the Bulgarian National Revenue Agency (NRA).

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to all employees, directors, officers, contractors, and agents of [Company Name] (hereinafter "the Company") operating within or from Bulgaria. It covers all business relationships, products, services, and transactions undertaken by the Company.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Beneficial Owner (BO):** The natural person(s) who ultimately owns or controls a customer and/or the natural person on whose behalf a transaction is being conducted.
*   **Customer Due Diligence (CDD):** The process of identifying the customer and verifying their identity using reliable, independent source documents, data, or information.
*   **Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD):** Enhanced measures applied to higher-risk customers, business relationships, or transactions.
*   **Financial Intelligence Directorate (FID):** The Bulgarian agency responsible for receiving, analyzing, and disseminating suspicious transaction/activity reports.
*   **Know Your Customer (KYC):** The overarching process encompassing CDD, including understanding the customer's business and risk profile.
*   **National Revenue Agency (NRA):** The designated supervisory authority for certain obligated entities under Bulgarian AML/CTF law.
*   **Politically Exposed Person (PEP):** A natural person who is or has been entrusted with prominent public functions, both domestic and foreign.
*   **Suspicious Transaction/Activity Report (STR/SAR):** A report filed with the FID when there are grounds to suspect that funds are the proceeds of criminal activity or are related to terrorist financing.
*   **Simplified Due Diligence (SDD):** Applicable only in strictly defined, lower-risk scenarios as per the law.

## 4. Policy Statement
The Company is committed to the highest standards of AML/CTF compliance. We expressly prohibit the use of our services for any activity related to money laundering, terrorist financing, or other illicit financial activities. Our program is risk-based, requiring the application of more rigorous controls where risks are higher. All personnel are required to adhere strictly to this policy, and failure to do so will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination, and may lead to regulatory penalties.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Risk Assessment
*   The Company will conduct and document a periodic (annual) Enterprise-Wide Risk Assessment (EWRA) to identify, assess, and understand its ML/TF risks related to customers, countries, products, services, transactions, and delivery channels.
*   The EWRA forms the basis for allocating compliance resources and determining the appropriate level of CDD.

### 5.2 Customer Identification and Verification (KYC/CDD)
#### 5.2.1 Standard CDD
For all new customers, the following must be obtained and verified *before* establishing a business relationship:
*   **For Natural Persons:** Full name, date of birth, nationality, unique identification number (e.g., Bulgarian Personal ID Number), and residential address.
*   **For Legal Entities:** Name, legal form, registration number, registered office address, and the identity of the persons authorized to act on its behalf.
*   **Identification of the Beneficial Owner(s):** Taking reasonable measures to identify and verify the identity of the BO(s) using relevant information from reliable sources.
*   **Purpose and Nature of the Business Relationship:** Understanding the intended purpose and nature of the relationship.

#### 5.2.2 Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD)
EDD measures are mandatory for higher-risk categories, including but not limited to:
*   Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs).
*   Customers from high-risk third countries as identified by the EU or FATF.
*   Complex or unusually large transactions, or unusual patterns of transactions with no apparent economic or lawful purpose.
*   Non-face-to-face business relationships.
EDD measures include obtaining additional information, obtaining senior management approval for establishing/continuing the relationship, and conducting enhanced ongoing monitoring.

#### 5.2.3 Simplified Due Diligence (SDD)
SDD may only be applied in circumstances explicitly defined as lower risk by the MAMLA and EU regulations. The decision to apply SDD must be justified and documented.

### 5.3 Ongoing Monitoring
*   All business relationships are subject to continuous monitoring to ensure transactions are consistent with the Company's knowledge of the customer, their business, and risk profile.
*   Customer documentation and KYC information will be kept up-to-date, with a formal review cycle based on customer risk rating (e.g., high-risk: annually; low-risk: every 3 years).

### 5.4 Transaction Monitoring & Screening
*   The Company will implement a system for monitoring customer transactions to identify patterns of activity that appear unusual or potentially suspicious.
*   All customers and related parties (BOs, authorized persons) will be screened against relevant sanctions lists (EU, UN, OFAC), PEP lists, and internal blacklists on a regular and ongoing basis.

### 5.5 Reporting Obligations
*   **Suspicious Activity Reporting:** Any employee who suspects or has reasonable grounds to suspect that funds are linked to ML/TF must immediately report their suspicions to the designated Compliance Officer. The Compliance Officer is responsible for evaluating the suspicion and, if warranted, filing a STR with the Bulgarian FID without delay. The reporting obligation and the existence of the STR are strictly confidential.
*   **Threshold Reporting:** Any cash transaction exceeding BGN 30,000 (or equivalent in foreign currency) must be recorded internally. The Company will comply with any mandatory reporting of such transactions as required by law.
*   **Other Reporting:** The Company will comply with all other regulatory reporting requirements to the NRA.

### 5.6 Record Keeping
All documents and data related to customer identification (KYC), business correspondence, and transaction records must be retained for a minimum period of **ten (10) years** from the termination of the business relationship or the date of the occasional transaction, in accordance with Bulgarian law.

### 5.7 Employee Training
All relevant employees will receive regular, documented AML/CTF training upon hiring and at least annually thereafter. Training will cover legal obligations, internal policies, red flag indicators, and reporting procedures.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   **Designated Compliance Officer:** The Company appoints a qualified AML Compliance Officer with the responsibility and authority to implement and oversee the day-to-day operations of the AML/CTF program.
*   **Management Oversight:** The Company's senior management is ultimately responsible for ensuring an effective AML/CTF program, providing adequate resources, and approving the EWRA and this policy.
*   **Employee Cooperation:** All employees are required to fully cooperate with the Compliance Officer and report any potential concerns without fear of retaliation.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy and the associated EWRA shall be formally reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually,** as a minimum.
*   Following any significant change in the Company's business model, products, or geographic reach.
*   Following major changes to the Bulgarian MAMLA, EU AMLD, or NRA guidance.
*   Following any material ML/TF incident or regulatory finding.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but is not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
*   **Primary National Law:** Bulgarian **Measures Against Money Laundering Act (MAMLA)**.
*   **EU Directives:** Directive (EU) 2015/849 (4th AMLD) as amended by Directive (EU) 2018/843 (5th AMLD) and Directive (EU) 2021/555 (6th AMLD).
*   **Supervisory Authority:** Decrees, guidelines, and instructions issued by the **Bulgarian National Revenue Agency (NRA)**.
*   **Reporting Authority:** Requirements and procedures of the **Bulgarian Financial Intelligence Directorate (FID)**.
*   **International Standards:** The Recommendations of the **Financial Action Task Force (FATF)**.

# ICT Risk Management, Incident Response, and Business Continuity Policy

## 1. Policy Title
**ICT Operational Resilience and Cybersecurity Policy**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for managing Information and Communication Technology (ICT) risk, responding to ICT-related incidents, and ensuring business continuity in the event of a severe disruption. It is designed to ensure the operational resilience of the organization by aligning with the requirements of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 (Digital Operational Resilience Act – DORA) and applicable Bulgarian cybersecurity legislation, including the Cybersecurity Act and regulations issued by the National Cybersecurity Coordinator.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff, and third-party service providers (ICT third-party service providers as defined by DORA) who access, manage, or support the organization's ICT systems, data, or processes.
*   All critical business functions and supporting ICT systems, including those outsourced to third parties.
*   All entities and branches of the organization operating within the Republic of Bulgaria and the European Union.

## 3. Definitions
*   **ICT Risk:** The risk of operational failure, disruption, or loss related to ICT systems, including cybersecurity risks.
*   **Operational Resilience:** The ability of an organization to continue to deliver critical operations through severe disruptions by preventing, adapting to, absorbing, and recovering from ICT-related incidents.
*   **ICT Incident:** Any single event or series of linked events that compromises the security, availability, integrity, or confidentiality of ICT systems or data.
*   **Major ICT Incident:** An ICT incident that has a severe impact on the continuity of critical functions or services, as defined by internal classification thresholds and regulatory reporting criteria.
*   **Business Continuity:** The capability of the organization to continue the delivery of products or services at acceptable predefined levels following a disruptive incident.
*   **ICT Third-Party Service Provider:** Any external provider of ICT services, including cloud computing, software, infrastructure, and support services.
*   **DORA:** Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 on digital operational resilience for the financial sector.
*   **NCSC:** National Cybersecurity Coordinator of Bulgaria.

## 4. Policy Statement
The organization is committed to achieving and maintaining a high level of digital operational resilience. This requires a proactive and systematic approach to identifying, managing, and mitigating ICT risks, ensuring preparedness for effective incident response, and maintaining robust business continuity capabilities. All personnel and relevant third parties are required to adhere to the principles and procedures outlined in this policy to protect the organization's assets, reputation, and legal standing.

## 5. Procedures
The policy is implemented through three interconnected frameworks:

### A. ICT Risk Management Framework
1.  **Governance:** The Management Board bears ultimate responsibility for ICT risk management. A designated ICT Risk Manager will oversee the framework's implementation.
2.  **Identification & Assessment:** A periodic ICT risk assessment shall be conducted to identify threats, vulnerabilities, and impacts on critical business functions. This includes mapping all ICT assets and dependencies.
3.  **Protection & Mitigation:** Based on the risk assessment, appropriate technical and organizational controls (e.g., access controls, encryption, network security, patch management) shall be implemented to reduce risk to an acceptable level.
4.  **Third-Party Risk Management:** A dedicated process for assessing, monitoring, and managing risks arising from ICT third-party service providers shall be established, including contractual safeguards aligned with DORA Title V.
5.  **Testing:** All critical ICT systems and controls will be subjected to regular advanced threat-led penetration testing (TLPT) and other resilience testing, as required by DORA.

### B. ICT Incident Response Plan
1.  **Incident Classification:** All ICT incidents shall be classified based on their severity (e.g., Low, Medium, High, Critical) using predefined criteria related to impact on operations, data confidentiality, and regulatory obligations.
2.  **Response Team:** A dedicated ICT Incident Response Team (IRT) shall be established with clearly defined roles and responsibilities.
3.  **Detection & Reporting:** Procedures for employees to detect and report suspected ICT incidents to the IT Service Desk/IRT shall be communicated and enforced.
4.  **Containment, Eradication & Recovery:** The IRT shall follow a documented playbook to contain the incident, eradicate the threat, and recover systems and data.
5.  **Communication:** Internal and external communication protocols (including communication with clients, authorities like the NCSC, and other regulators) shall be followed during a major incident.
6.  **Post-Incident Review:** A root cause analysis and lessons-learned review shall be conducted after every major incident to improve defenses and response procedures.

### C. Business Continuity Procedures
1.  **Business Impact Analysis (BIA):** A BIA shall identify and prioritize critical business functions, their maximum tolerable downtime, and their dependencies on ICT systems and personnel.
2.  **Continuity Strategies:** For each critical function, recovery strategies shall be documented, including backup solutions, alternative work locations, and manual workarounds where feasible.
3.  **Business Continuity Plan (BCP):** A formal BCP shall document the steps to activate, execute, and return to normal operations following a severe disruption.
4.  **Backup & Restoration:** Critical data and systems shall be backed up regularly. The integrity and restoration capability of backups shall be tested periodically.
5.  **Training & Awareness:** All staff shall receive basic training on their role during a disruption. Key personnel in the IRT and BCP teams shall undergo regular exercises.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   All employees must complete mandatory annual training on cybersecurity awareness and their responsibilities under this policy.
*   Managers are responsible for ensuring their teams comply with relevant security and continuity procedures.
*   The ICT department is responsible for implementing technical controls and monitoring compliance.
*   Non-compliance with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract.
*   The organization is obligated to report major ICT incidents to the relevant Bulgarian authorities (NCSC) and, where applicable, to European supervisory authorities as mandated by DORA.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy and its subordinate plans (Incident Response, Business Continuity) shall be reviewed at least **annually**, or more frequently in response to:
*   Significant changes in the threat landscape or business operations.
*   The outcome of a major incident or resilience test.
*   Changes in applicable regulatory requirements (EU or Bulgarian).
All updates must be approved by the Management Board.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but is not limited to, the following regulations:
*   **Regulation (EU) 2022/2554:** The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) – Titles II (ICT Risk Management), III (ICT Incident Reporting), IV (Digital Operational Resilience Testing), and V (ICT Third-Party Risk).
*   **Bulgarian Cybersecurity Act** (Закон за киберсигурността) and its implementing regulations.
*   **Directives and Guidelines** issued by the National Cybersecurity Coordinator (NCSC) of Bulgaria.
*   **General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)** (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) concerning personal data breach notification.

Market Conduct and Transparency Policy for Stablecoin Trading Activities

### 2.1 Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to establish a robust framework to ensure fair, orderly, and transparent trading of stablecoins, in full compliance with the market conduct and transparency requirements set forth in Articles 41-45 of the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA). This policy aims to prevent market abuse, ensure integrity, and promote investor confidence in our trading platforms and activities.

This policy applies to:
*   All employees, contractors, and agents of [Company Name] (hereinafter "the Firm").
*   All trading activities involving asset-referenced tokens and e-money tokens (collectively "stablecoins") conducted on proprietary accounts or on behalf of clients.
*   All relevant business units including Trading, Sales, Compliance, Risk, and Technology.
*   All trading venues and platforms operated by the Firm.

## 3. Definitions

*   **Market Abuse:** Behaviors including, but not limited to, insider dealing, unlawful disclosure of inside information, and market manipulation as defined under MiCA and relevant national laws.
*   **Market Manipulation:** Any transaction, order, or behavior that: (a) gives, or is likely to give, false or misleading signals as to the supply, demand, or price of a stablecoin; or (b) secures the price of a stablecoin at an abnormal or artificial level.
*   **Inside Information:** Specific information of a precise nature, relating directly or indirectly to one or more stablecoins, which has not been made public and which, if made public, would likely have a significant effect on the price of that stablecoin.
*   **Surveillance:** The ongoing monitoring and analysis of trading data, orders, and communications to identify potential market abuse or conduct violations.
*   **Transparency Data:** Pre-trade and post-trade information required to be disclosed to the market, including bid/ask quotes, depth, and details of executed transactions.
*   **Stablecoin:** For the purposes of this policy, refers to both "asset-referenced tokens" and "e-money tokens" as defined under MiCA Title III and IV.

## 4. Policy Statement

The Firm is committed to upholding the highest standards of market integrity and transparency. We strictly prohibit any form of market abuse, including insider dealing and market manipulation, in relation to stablecoin trading activities. The Firm will implement and maintain effective organizational and administrative arrangements, including surveillance mechanisms and transparency protocols, to prevent, detect, and report conduct that contravenes MiCA Articles 41-45. All personnel are required to act with due skill, care, and diligence, placing the integrity of the market and the interests of clients above all.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Market Conduct & Prohibited Activities
All personnel are prohibited from engaging in, attempting, or facilitating:
*   **Insider Dealing:** Trading based on inside information.
*   **Unlawful Disclosure:** Improperly disclosing inside information.
*   **Market Manipulation:** Including, but not limited to:
    *   Wash trades (matching buy and sell orders without beneficial ownership change).
    *   Spoofing (placing orders with intent to cancel before execution).
    *   Layering (placing multiple non-bona fide orders on one side of the book to create false liquidity or price movement).
    *   Pump-and-dump schemes.
    *   Creating misleading transactions or orders concerning the supply, demand, or price of a stablecoin.

### 5.2 Surveillance Mechanisms
1.  **Automated Surveillance System:** The Compliance Department, in conjunction with Technology, will implement an automated trade surveillance system capable of monitoring all trading activity in real-time and via post-trade analysis. The system will be calibrated to detect patterns indicative of market abuse.
2.  **Alert Review:** The Compliance Department will review all system-generated alerts promptly. Investigations will be documented, and findings reported in accordance with internal escalation procedures.
3.  **Communication Surveillance:** Relevant electronic communications (e.g., chat, email) of staff in covered roles will be subject to monitoring and review.
4.  **Whistleblowing:** A secure and confidential channel will be maintained for employees to report suspected market abuse.

### 5.3 Transparency Protocols
1.  **Pre-Trade Transparency:** For any trading venue operated by the Firm, current bid and offer prices and the depth of trading interest at those prices will be made public continuously during trading hours, as required by MiCA.
2.  **Post-Trade Transparency:** The price, volume, and time of all transactions in stablecoins executed via the Firm's systems will be made public as close to real-time as technically possible.
3.  **Data Publication:** Transparency data will be published via a standardized data feed in a machine-readable format.
4.  **Deferrals & Exemptions:** Any application of permissible deferrals or exemptions to transparency requirements (e.g., for large-in-scale transactions) must be pre-approved by the Compliance Department and properly documented.

### 5.4 Insider Information Management
1.  **Identification:** Business heads are responsible for identifying information that may constitute inside information.
2.  **Control:** Inside information must be kept confidential. Access is restricted on a need-to-know basis.
3.  **Insider Lists:** The Compliance Department will create and maintain precise, up-to-date insider lists for any relevant stablecoin issuers or projects where the Firm possesses inside information, as required.

## 6. Compliance Requirements

### 6.1 Training
All covered employees must complete mandatory annual training on market conduct rules, this policy, and the procedures for identifying and reporting market abuse.

### 6.2 Record Keeping
The Firm will maintain complete and accurate records of all transactions, orders (including cancellations), communications, surveillance alerts, investigations, and training for a minimum period of five years, in accordance with MiCA requirements.

### 6.3 Reporting
1.  **Internal Reporting:** Suspected violations of this policy must be reported immediately to the Compliance Department or via the whistleblowing channel.
2.  **External Reporting:** The Compliance Department is responsible for reporting any reasonable suspicion of market abuse to the relevant competent authority without delay, as mandated by MiCA Article 79.

### 6.4 Accountability
Violations of this policy will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment, and may lead to regulatory sanctions and criminal prosecution.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule

*   **Annually** by the Compliance Department to ensure its continued effectiveness and relevance.
*   **Immediately** following any material change in MiCA regulations or relevant national implementing measures.
*   Following any significant internal incident or control failure related to market conduct.

All updates must be approved by the Chief Compliance Officer and communicated to all relevant staff.

**Crypto-Asset Tax Compliance and Reporting Policy (Bulgarian Jurisdiction)**

The purpose of this policy is to establish clear guidelines and procedures to ensure the Company's full compliance with Bulgarian tax legislation regarding the acquisition, disposal, trading, and use of crypto-assets. *   **Acquisition Cost:** The total cost incurred to acquire a crypto-asset, including purchase price, transaction fees, and any directly attributable costs.
*   **Proceeds from Disposal:** The market value in Bulgarian Lev (BGN) of the consideration received upon disposal of a crypto-asset at the time of the transaction.
*   **Taxable Gain/Loss:** The difference between the Proceeds from Disposal and the Acquisition Cost of the crypto-asset.
*   **NRA (National Revenue Agency):** The Bulgarian government agency responsible for the assessment and collection of taxes.

## 4. Policy Statement
It is the policy of the Company to comply fully with all applicable Bulgarian tax laws and regulations concerning crypto-assets. The Company will:
*   Recognize all crypto-asset transactions for tax purposes in accordance with Bulgarian legislation.
*   Calculate, declare, and pay all due taxes, including Corporate Income Tax on trading gains and Value Added Tax (VAT) where applicable, accurately and on time.
*   Maintain complete, accurate, and auditable records of all crypto-asset transactions.
*   Assign clear roles and responsibilities for tax compliance management.
*   Prohibit any activity designed to evade tax obligations or misrepresent the nature of crypto-asset transactions.

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1 Transaction Recording & Documentation
1.  **Record Keeping:** The Finance Department must maintain a dedicated, secure ledger for all crypto-asset transactions. Each entry must include:
    *   Date and time (UTC) of transaction.
    *   Type of transaction (buy, sell, exchange, receipt as payment).
    *   Amount and type of crypto-asset.
    *   Counterparty information (exchange, wallet address, etc.).
    *   Transaction hash/ID.
    *   Acquisition Cost or Proceeds from Disposal converted to BGN using a consistent and verifiable source (e.g., average exchange rate from a reputable platform at the transaction timestamp).
    *   Calculation of any taxable gain or loss.

2.  **Supporting Documents:** All wallet statements, exchange trade confirmations, invoices, and agreements related to crypto-asset transactions must be stored electronically in the designated compliance repository for a minimum of **10 years** from the end of the relevant tax year.

### 5.2 Tax Calculation and Reporting
1.  **Corporate Income Tax (CIT):**
    *   Taxable gains from crypto-asset disposals are included in the Company's taxable profit and subject to the standard CIT rate (currently 10%).
    *   Losses from disposals are recognized and can be carried forward according to Bulgarian tax law.
    *   The Finance Department is responsible for quarterly provisional CIT calculations and annual CIT return preparation, incorporating crypto-asset gains/losses.

2.  **Value Added Tax (VAT):**
    *   The exchange of crypto-asset for fiat currency (BGN, EUR, etc.) is treated as a supply of services and is **exempt from VAT** under the Bulgarian implementation of EU VAT Directive (Article 135(1)(e)).
    *   The supply of goods or services in return for crypto-asset payment is subject to standard VAT rules based on the nature of the underlying good/service supplied. VAT is calculated on the BGN value of the crypto-asset at the time of supply.
    *   The Finance Department must ensure correct VAT treatment on invoices and in the VAT return.

3.  **Annual Reporting:** All crypto-asset holdings and transactions must be accurately reflected in the Company's annual financial statements and tax returns filed with the NRA.

### 5.3 Responsibility Matrix
*   **Head of Finance:** Ultimate responsibility for tax compliance; signs off on annual tax returns.
*   **Finance Manager / Tax Specialist:** Executes procedures, performs calculations, prepares filings, maintains records, and monitors regulatory changes.
*   **All Employees:** Must report any Company-related crypto-asset transaction to the Finance Department immediately and are prohibited from engaging in unauthorized transactions.

*   **Internal Review:** The Finance Department will conduct a semi-annual internal audit of crypto-asset transactions and tax calculations.
*   **External Audit:** Records must be readily available for review by external auditors and the NRA.
*   **Consequences of Non-Compliance:** Failure to comply may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment, and may expose the individual and the Company to significant financial penalties, interest charges, and legal prosecution by the NRA.

# Stablecoin Capital Adequacy and Reserve Management Policy

## 1. Policy Title
**Capital Adequacy, Reserve Management, and Liquidity Protocol Policy for Asset-Referenced Token (ART) and E-Money Token (EMT) Issuance**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to ensure [Company Name] maintains adequate capital, holds sufficient reserves, and implements robust liquidity protocols for all issued stablecoins (categorized as Asset-Referenced Tokens (ARTs) or E-Money Tokens (EMTs) under MiCA). The primary objectives are to:
*   Ensure full 1:1 backing of all tokens in circulation with high-quality liquid assets.
*   Maintain capital buffers to absorb potential losses and ensure operational resilience.
*   Guarantee daily redemption rights for token holders.
*   Ensure full compliance with Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (Markets in Crypto-Assets - MiCA), specifically Articles 31-35.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to all departments, personnel, and third-party service providers involved in the issuance, management, reserve custody, redemption, and liquidity provisioning of [Company Name]'s stablecoins. It covers all stages of the token lifecycle.

## 3. Definitions
*   **ART (Asset-Referenced Token):** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing another value or right, or a combination thereof, including one or more official currencies.
*   **EMT (E-Money Token):** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing the value of one official currency.
*   **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA):** Assets as defined in MiCA Article 32(3) and further specified in this policy, which are highly liquid, low-risk, and can be easily and immediately converted to cash to meet redemption requests.
*   **Reserve of Assets:** The total pool of assets backing the stablecoins in circulation, maintained on a 1:1 basis.
*   **Capital Buffer:** Own funds held by the issuer in addition to the reserve of assets, intended to cover operational risks and potential losses.
*   **Liquidity Protocol:** The operational procedures and systems that ensure the timely processing of redemptions and management of the reserve portfolio.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to operating with the highest standards of transparency, security, and regulatory compliance. We hereby mandate:
1.  **1:1 Backing Requirement:** At all times, the value of the Reserve of Assets must equal or exceed the aggregate value of all stablecoins issued and in circulation.
2.  **HQLA Reserve Composition:** The Reserve of Assets shall be composed exclusively of High-Quality Liquid Assets as defined in Section 5.1. The reserve shall be segregated, ring-fenced, and held with regulated custodians.
3.  **Capital Adequacy:** [Company Name] shall maintain a permanent capital buffer (own funds) in accordance with the higher of: (a) the requirements of MiCA Article 35, or (b) 2% of the average amount of the reserve assets.
4.  **Daily Redemption:** All token holders have the right to redeem their tokens at par value, in the referenced currency, on any business day.
5.  **Prohibition of Interest:** No interest shall be paid to stablecoin holders.
6.  **Transparency:** Regular, detailed reports on the composition, valuation, and audit results of the Reserve of Assets will be published.

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1 Reserve Asset Management
*   **Eligible Assets:** The Reserve of Assets may only include:
    *   Deposits with credit institutions.
    *   Government bonds (sovereign debt) from EEA Member States, with a credit assessment of at least 1 from a recognized agency.
    *   High-quality corporate bonds.
    *   Short-term money market instruments.
    *   **Explicitly Excluded:** No crypto-assets, own funds, or illiquid assets shall be included in the reserve.
*   **Custody:** All reserve assets must be held with one or more EU-authorized credit institutions or investment firms. A minimum of two-thirds of the reserve must be held in deposits.
*   **Diversification:** No single asset or issuer (excluding sovereign debt of EEA states) shall constitute more than 5% of the total reserve.
*   **Valuation:** The reserve portfolio shall be valued daily at mark-to-market or mark-to-model prices by the Finance Department.

### 5.2 Capital Buffer Calculation & Maintenance
*   The Capital Buffer shall be calculated monthly based on the average amount of reserve assets over the preceding six months.
*   The buffer must be held in liquid assets, separate from the operational accounts of the company.
*   The buffer can only be used to cover operational losses and must be replenished within 30 days if utilized.

### 5.3 Liquidity and Redemption Protocol
1.  **Redemption Request Submission:** Token holders may submit redemption requests 24/7 through the official platform.
2.  **Processing Timeline:** Requests received on a business day before 12:00 PM CET will be processed for same-day settlement (T+1). Later requests will be processed the next business day.
3.  **Settlement:** Redemptions are settled via bank transfer to a verified account in the referenced fiat currency.
4.  **Liquidity Stress Testing:** The Treasury Department will conduct weekly stress tests simulating extreme redemption scenarios (e.g., 20% of tokens redeemed in 24 hours) to ensure the HQLA portfolio can be liquidated without significant loss.

### 5.4 Audit and Reporting
*   **Internal Reporting:** Daily reserve composition and valuation reports to the Chief Compliance Officer (CCO) and Chief Financial Officer (CFO).
*   **External Audit:** A quarterly statutory audit of the Reserve of Assets by an independent, EU-authorized auditor.
*   **Public Disclosure:** Publication of a monthly Reserve Report on the company website, detailing the breakdown of assets, their valuations, and the auditor's attestation.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   The **Chief Compliance Officer (CCO)** is the policy owner and is responsible for overall oversight.
*   The **Treasury Department** is responsible for the day-to-day management, investment, and rebalancing of the Reserve of Assets.
*   The **Finance Department** is responsible for daily valuation, capital buffer calculation, and financial reporting.
*   The **Technology Department** is responsible for implementing and maintaining the technical systems for the redemption protocol.
*   All employees must complete annual training on this policy.
*   Any breach or suspected breach of this policy must be reported immediately to the CCO.

*   **Annually** as part of the standard compliance review cycle.

*   **Ad-hoc** following any internal incident affecting reserves or liquidity.

### 2.1 Purpose

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Risk Assessment
*   The Company will conduct and document a periodic (annual) Enterprise-Wide Risk Assessment (EWRA) to identify, assess, and understand its ML/TF risks related to customers, countries, products, services, transactions, and delivery channels.
*   The EWRA forms the basis for allocating compliance resources and determining the appropriate level of CDD.

### 5.2 Customer Identification and Verification (KYC/CDD)
#### 5.2.1 Standard CDD
For all new customers, the following must be obtained and verified *before* establishing a business relationship:
*   **For Natural Persons:** Full name, date of birth, nationality, unique identification number (e.g., Bulgarian Personal ID Number), and residential address.
*   **For Legal Entities:** Name, legal form, registration number, registered office address, and the identity of the persons authorized to act on its behalf.
*   **Identification of the Beneficial Owner(s):** Taking reasonable measures to identify and verify the identity of the BO(s) using relevant information from reliable sources.
*   **Purpose and Nature of the Business Relationship:** Understanding the intended purpose and nature of the relationship.

#### 5.2.2 Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD)
EDD measures are mandatory for higher-risk categories, including but not limited to:
*   Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs).
*   Customers from high-risk third countries as identified by the EU or FATF.
*   Complex or unusually large transactions, or unusual patterns of transactions with no apparent economic or lawful purpose.
*   Non-face-to-face business relationships.
EDD measures include obtaining additional information, obtaining senior management approval for establishing/continuing the relationship, and conducting enhanced ongoing monitoring.

#### 5.2.3 Simplified Due Diligence (SDD)
SDD may only be applied in circumstances explicitly defined as lower risk by the MAMLA and EU regulations. The decision to apply SDD must be justified and documented.

### 5.3 Ongoing Monitoring
*   All business relationships are subject to continuous monitoring to ensure transactions are consistent with the Company's knowledge of the customer, their business, and risk profile.
*   Customer documentation and KYC information will be kept up-to-date, with a formal review cycle based on customer risk rating (e.g., high-risk: annually; low-risk: every 3 years).

### 5.4 Transaction Monitoring & Screening
*   The Company will implement a system for monitoring customer transactions to identify patterns of activity that appear unusual or potentially suspicious.
*   All customers and related parties (BOs, authorized persons) will be screened against relevant sanctions lists (EU, UN, OFAC), PEP lists, and internal blacklists on a regular and ongoing basis.

### 5.5 Reporting Obligations
*   **Suspicious Activity Reporting:** Any employee who suspects or has reasonable grounds to suspect that funds are linked to ML/TF must immediately report their suspicions to the designated Compliance Officer. The Compliance Officer is responsible for evaluating the suspicion and, if warranted, filing a STR with the Bulgarian FID without delay. The reporting obligation and the existence of the STR are strictly confidential.
*   **Threshold Reporting:** Any cash transaction exceeding BGN 30,000 (or equivalent in foreign currency) must be recorded internally. The Company will comply with any mandatory reporting of such transactions as required by law.
*   **Other Reporting:** The Company will comply with all other regulatory reporting requirements to the NRA.

### 5.6 Record Keeping
All documents and data related to customer identification (KYC), business correspondence, and transaction records must be retained for a minimum period of **ten (10) years** from the termination of the business relationship or the date of the occasional transaction, in accordance with Bulgarian law.

### 5.7 Employee Training
All relevant employees will receive regular, documented AML/CTF training upon hiring and at least annually thereafter. Training will cover legal obligations, internal policies, red flag indicators, and reporting procedures.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   **Designated Compliance Officer:** The Company appoints a qualified AML Compliance Officer with the responsibility and authority to implement and oversee the day-to-day operations of the AML/CTF program.
*   **Management Oversight:** The Company's senior management is ultimately responsible for ensuring an effective AML/CTF program, providing adequate resources, and approving the EWRA and this policy.
*   **Employee Cooperation:** All employees are required to fully cooperate with the Compliance Officer and report any potential concerns without fear of retaliation.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy and the associated EWRA shall be formally reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually,** as a minimum.
*   Following any significant change in the Company's business model, products, or geographic reach.
*   Following major changes to the Bulgarian MAMLA, EU AMLD, or NRA guidance.
*   Following any material ML/TF incident or regulatory finding.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but is not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
*   **Primary National Law:** Bulgarian **Measures Against Money Laundering Act (MAMLA)**.
*   **EU Directives:** Directive (EU) 2015/849 (4th AMLD) as amended by Directive (EU) 2018/843 (5th AMLD) and Directive (EU) 2021/555 (6th AMLD).
*   **Supervisory Authority:** Decrees, guidelines, and instructions issued by the **Bulgarian National Revenue Agency (NRA)**.
*   **Reporting Authority:** Requirements and procedures of the **Bulgarian Financial Intelligence Directorate (FID)**.
*   **International Standards:** The Recommendations of the **Financial Action Task Force (FATF)**.

# ICT Risk Management, Incident Response, and Business Continuity Policy

## 1. Policy Title
**ICT Operational Resilience and Cybersecurity Policy**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for managing Information and Communication Technology (ICT) risk, responding to ICT-related incidents, and ensuring business continuity in the event of a severe disruption. It is designed to ensure the operational resilience of the organization by aligning with the requirements of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 (Digital Operational Resilience Act – DORA) and applicable Bulgarian cybersecurity legislation, including the Cybersecurity Act and regulations issued by the National Cybersecurity Coordinator.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff, and third-party service providers (ICT third-party service providers as defined by DORA) who access, manage, or support the organization's ICT systems, data, or processes.
*   All critical business functions and supporting ICT systems, including those outsourced to third parties.
*   All entities and branches of the organization operating within the Republic of Bulgaria and the European Union.

## 3. Definitions
*   **ICT Risk:** The risk of operational failure, disruption, or loss related to ICT systems, including cybersecurity risks.
*   **Operational Resilience:** The ability of an organization to continue to deliver critical operations through severe disruptions by preventing, adapting to, absorbing, and recovering from ICT-related incidents.
*   **ICT Incident:** Any single event or series of linked events that compromises the security, availability, integrity, or confidentiality of ICT systems or data.
*   **Major ICT Incident:** An ICT incident that has a severe impact on the continuity of critical functions or services, as defined by internal classification thresholds and regulatory reporting criteria.
*   **Business Continuity:** The capability of the organization to continue the delivery of products or services at acceptable predefined levels following a disruptive incident.
*   **ICT Third-Party Service Provider:** Any external provider of ICT services, including cloud computing, software, infrastructure, and support services.
*   **DORA:** Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 on digital operational resilience for the financial sector.
*   **NCSC:** National Cybersecurity Coordinator of Bulgaria.

## 4. Policy Statement
The organization is committed to achieving and maintaining a high level of digital operational resilience. This requires a proactive and systematic approach to identifying, managing, and mitigating ICT risks, ensuring preparedness for effective incident response, and maintaining robust business continuity capabilities. All personnel and relevant third parties are required to adhere to the principles and procedures outlined in this policy to protect the organization's assets, reputation, and legal standing.

## 5. Procedures
The policy is implemented through three interconnected frameworks:

### A. ICT Risk Management Framework
1.  **Governance:** The Management Board bears ultimate responsibility for ICT risk management. A designated ICT Risk Manager will oversee the framework's implementation.
2.  **Identification & Assessment:** A periodic ICT risk assessment shall be conducted to identify threats, vulnerabilities, and impacts on critical business functions. This includes mapping all ICT assets and dependencies.
3.  **Protection & Mitigation:** Based on the risk assessment, appropriate technical and organizational controls (e.g., access controls, encryption, network security, patch management) shall be implemented to reduce risk to an acceptable level.
4.  **Third-Party Risk Management:** A dedicated process for assessing, monitoring, and managing risks arising from ICT third-party service providers shall be established, including contractual safeguards aligned with DORA Title V.
5.  **Testing:** All critical ICT systems and controls will be subjected to regular advanced threat-led penetration testing (TLPT) and other resilience testing, as required by DORA.

### B. ICT Incident Response Plan
1.  **Incident Classification:** All ICT incidents shall be classified based on their severity (e.g., Low, Medium, High, Critical) using predefined criteria related to impact on operations, data confidentiality, and regulatory obligations.
2.  **Response Team:** A dedicated ICT Incident Response Team (IRT) shall be established with clearly defined roles and responsibilities.
3.  **Detection & Reporting:** Procedures for employees to detect and report suspected ICT incidents to the IT Service Desk/IRT shall be communicated and enforced.
4.  **Containment, Eradication & Recovery:** The IRT shall follow a documented playbook to contain the incident, eradicate the threat, and recover systems and data.
5.  **Communication:** Internal and external communication protocols (including communication with clients, authorities like the NCSC, and other regulators) shall be followed during a major incident.
6.  **Post-Incident Review:** A root cause analysis and lessons-learned review shall be conducted after every major incident to improve defenses and response procedures.

### C. Business Continuity Procedures
1.  **Business Impact Analysis (BIA):** A BIA shall identify and prioritize critical business functions, their maximum tolerable downtime, and their dependencies on ICT systems and personnel.
2.  **Continuity Strategies:** For each critical function, recovery strategies shall be documented, including backup solutions, alternative work locations, and manual workarounds where feasible.
3.  **Business Continuity Plan (BCP):** A formal BCP shall document the steps to activate, execute, and return to normal operations following a severe disruption.
4.  **Backup & Restoration:** Critical data and systems shall be backed up regularly. The integrity and restoration capability of backups shall be tested periodically.
5.  **Training & Awareness:** All staff shall receive basic training on their role during a disruption. Key personnel in the IRT and BCP teams shall undergo regular exercises.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   All employees must complete mandatory annual training on cybersecurity awareness and their responsibilities under this policy.
*   Managers are responsible for ensuring their teams comply with relevant security and continuity procedures.
*   The ICT department is responsible for implementing technical controls and monitoring compliance.
*   Non-compliance with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract.
*   The organization is obligated to report major ICT incidents to the relevant Bulgarian authorities (NCSC) and, where applicable, to European supervisory authorities as mandated by DORA.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy and its subordinate plans (Incident Response, Business Continuity) shall be reviewed at least **annually**, or more frequently in response to:
*   Significant changes in the threat landscape or business operations.
*   The outcome of a major incident or resilience test.
*   Changes in applicable regulatory requirements (EU or Bulgarian).
All updates must be approved by the Management Board.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but is not limited to, the following regulations:
*   **Regulation (EU) 2022/2554:** The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) – Titles II (ICT Risk Management), III (ICT Incident Reporting), IV (Digital Operational Resilience Testing), and V (ICT Third-Party Risk).

*   **Directives and Guidelines** issued by the National Cybersecurity Coordinator (NCSC) of Bulgaria.
*   **General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)** (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) concerning personal data breach notification.

Market Conduct and Transparency Policy for Stablecoin Trading Activities

## 2. Purpose and Scope

### 2.1 Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to establish a robust framework to ensure fair, orderly, and transparent trading of stablecoins, in full compliance with the market conduct and transparency requirements set forth in Articles 41-45 of the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA). This policy aims to prevent market abuse, ensure integrity, and promote investor confidence in our trading platforms and activities.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All employees, contractors, and agents of [Company Name] (hereinafter "the Firm").
*   All trading activities involving asset-referenced tokens and e-money tokens (collectively "stablecoins") conducted on proprietary accounts or on behalf of clients.
*   All relevant business units including Trading, Sales, Compliance, Risk, and Technology.
*   All trading venues and platforms operated by the Firm.

## 3. Definitions

*   **Market Abuse:** Behaviors including, but not limited to, insider dealing, unlawful disclosure of inside information, and market manipulation as defined under MiCA and relevant national laws.
*   **Market Manipulation:** Any transaction, order, or behavior that: (a) gives, or is likely to give, false or misleading signals as to the supply, demand, or price of a stablecoin; or (b) secures the price of a stablecoin at an abnormal or artificial level.
*   **Inside Information:** Specific information of a precise nature, relating directly or indirectly to one or more stablecoins, which has not been made public and which, if made public, would likely have a significant effect on the price of that stablecoin.
*   **Surveillance:** The ongoing monitoring and analysis of trading data, orders, and communications to identify potential market abuse or conduct violations.
*   **Transparency Data:** Pre-trade and post-trade information required to be disclosed to the market, including bid/ask quotes, depth, and details of executed transactions.
*   **Stablecoin:** For the purposes of this policy, refers to both "asset-referenced tokens" and "e-money tokens" as defined under MiCA Title III and IV.

## 4. Policy Statement

The Firm is committed to upholding the highest standards of market integrity and transparency. We strictly prohibit any form of market abuse, including insider dealing and market manipulation, in relation to stablecoin trading activities. The Firm will implement and maintain effective organizational and administrative arrangements, including surveillance mechanisms and transparency protocols, to prevent, detect, and report conduct that contravenes MiCA Articles 41-45. All personnel are required to act with due skill, care, and diligence, placing the integrity of the market and the interests of clients above all.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Market Conduct & Prohibited Activities
All personnel are prohibited from engaging in, attempting, or facilitating:
*   **Insider Dealing:** Trading based on inside information.
*   **Unlawful Disclosure:** Improperly disclosing inside information.
*   **Market Manipulation:** Including, but not limited to:
    *   Wash trades (matching buy and sell orders without beneficial ownership change).
    *   Spoofing (placing orders with intent to cancel before execution).
    *   Layering (placing multiple non-bona fide orders on one side of the book to create false liquidity or price movement).
    *   Pump-and-dump schemes.
    *   Creating misleading transactions or orders concerning the supply, demand, or price of a stablecoin.

### 5.2 Surveillance Mechanisms
1.  **Automated Surveillance System:** The Compliance Department, in conjunction with Technology, will implement an automated trade surveillance system capable of monitoring all trading activity in real-time and via post-trade analysis. The system will be calibrated to detect patterns indicative of market abuse.
2.  **Alert Review:** The Compliance Department will review all system-generated alerts promptly. Investigations will be documented, and findings reported in accordance with internal escalation procedures.
3.  **Communication Surveillance:** Relevant electronic communications (e.g., chat, email) of staff in covered roles will be subject to monitoring and review.
4.  **Whistleblowing:** A secure and confidential channel will be maintained for employees to report suspected market abuse.

### 5.3 Transparency Protocols
1.  **Pre-Trade Transparency:** For any trading venue operated by the Firm, current bid and offer prices and the depth of trading interest at those prices will be made public continuously during trading hours, as required by MiCA.
2.  **Post-Trade Transparency:** The price, volume, and time of all transactions in stablecoins executed via the Firm's systems will be made public as close to real-time as technically possible.
3.  **Data Publication:** Transparency data will be published via a standardized data feed in a machine-readable format.
4.  **Deferrals & Exemptions:** Any application of permissible deferrals or exemptions to transparency requirements (e.g., for large-in-scale transactions) must be pre-approved by the Compliance Department and properly documented.

### 5.4 Insider Information Management
1.  **Identification:** Business heads are responsible for identifying information that may constitute inside information.
2.  **Control:** Inside information must be kept confidential. Access is restricted on a need-to-know basis.
3.  **Insider Lists:** The Compliance Department will create and maintain precise, up-to-date insider lists for any relevant stablecoin issuers or projects where the Firm possesses inside information, as required.

## 6. Compliance Requirements

### 6.1 Training
All covered employees must complete mandatory annual training on market conduct rules, this policy, and the procedures for identifying and reporting market abuse.

### 6.2 Record Keeping
The Firm will maintain complete and accurate records of all transactions, orders (including cancellations), communications, surveillance alerts, investigations, and training for a minimum period of five years, in accordance with MiCA requirements.

### 6.3 Reporting
1.  **Internal Reporting:** Suspected violations of this policy must be reported immediately to the Compliance Department or via the whistleblowing channel.
2.  **External Reporting:** The Compliance Department is responsible for reporting any reasonable suspicion of market abuse to the relevant competent authority without delay, as mandated by MiCA Article 79.

### 6.4 Accountability
Violations of this policy will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment, and may lead to regulatory sanctions and criminal prosecution.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule

*   **Annually** by the Compliance Department to ensure its continued effectiveness and relevance.
*   **Immediately** following any material change in MiCA regulations or relevant national implementing measures.
